description: A rich, creamy, and nutty sauce made from pure groundnut (peanut) paste. It is a versatile and beloved sauce that can be served with meats, vegetables, or simply poured over staples like Posho and Matoke. Its deep, savory flavor is a cornerstone of Ugandan cuisine.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: Groundnut sauce is a unifying element in Ugandan food culture. Its richness makes everyday meals feel special, and it is a key ingredient in the ceremonial dish Luwombo. It is a common sight in both rural and urban kitchens, valued for its ability to transform simple ingredients into a flavorful and nutritious meal.

steps.instruction: In a bowl, gradually mix the groundnut paste with about 1 cup of water, whisking until you have a smooth, lump-free, creamy liquid.
Pour the groundnut mixture into a saucepan. Add the remaining 2 cups of water, chopped onion, and tomato (if using).
Place the saucepan over medium heat and bring to a gentle simmer, stirring frequently to prevent sticking.
Once simmering, reduce the heat to low. Continue to cook, stirring often, for 15-20 minutes until the sauce thickens to a creamy, gravy-like consistency.

cooking_indicators.visual: The sauce will coat the back of a spoon and the oil may start to separate slightly on the surface.

steps.instruction: Stir in the salt. Taste and adjust seasoning if necessary.
If the sauce becomes too thick, add a little more hot water to reach your desired consistency.
Serve the hot groundnut sauce over your chosen dish.

serving_suggestions: Pour generously over Posho (Ugali), Matoke, or Rice. It can also be used as a stew for boiled potatoes, sweet potatoes, or meat. It is a perfect companion for leafy greens like Sukuma Wiki.
